newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta property market seen buoyant in Q3.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta property market seen buoyant in Q3.

text.p: Jakarta's property market remained buoyant in the third quarter of the year but fresh supply caused occupancy rates to decline, property consultant Jones Lang Wootton (JLW) said on Wednesday.
"During the third quarter of 1996, demand in most sectors of the Jakarta property market remained buoyant," Craig Williams, a director of JLW Pacific, said.
JLW said in its quarterly report that net take-ups and fresh entries in the office market in prime locations increased by almost 50 percent over the previous quarter.
It said financial, telecommunication, manufacturing, trading and service firms were the sources of the new demand.
"But new supply was higher than the net take-up, causing overall occupancy levels to decline to 89.3 percent from 91.0 percent in the previous quarter," JLW said.
It said average rents remained stable at $13.0 per square meter per month despite the high level of demand.
JLW said fresh demand for retail space was dampened by lack of new stock in the third quarter.
It said there was aggressive expansion in the retail market which was expected to impact on demand levels for retail space over the next 12 months.
It said average occupancy rates at the end of September were 90.5 percent, 1.3 percent higher than the second quarter.
JLW said average rental rates for primary and secondary retail space remained unchanged in the third quarter.

It said the high volume of new apartment supply caused tenant-occupancy levels in the residential market to fall to 66.3 from 72.7 percent, but cumulative demand for existing condominiums was still stable at approximately 78 percent.
